Description.p: Attendance allowance (AA) is a beneﬁt for people aged 65 and over with attention or supervision needs. There is a higher rate and a lower rate, the rules of which are similar to those for the highest and middle rates of the disability living allowance (DLA) care component respectively (see ►). Unlike DLA, AA does not have a mobility component.

Parameter.name: test_generosity
Parameter.Description: We impute AA using a probit based on characteristics including age and disability levels. Leave this at zero to generate the current caseload given characteristics. Setting this to -0.5 reduces caseload by 50% (for current population characteristics). 0.5 increases caseload by 50% (for current population characteristics).

ParameterSystem.name: dla
ParameterSystem.Description:
Disability Living Allowance (DLA). See CPAG Guide ch 7.
Disability living allowance (DLA) is a beneﬁt for those who are under 65 when they claim. Although it has two separate care and mobility components, DLA is a single beneﬁt for which you only have to make one claim. Each component can be paid at different rates. Attendance allowance (AA) is a beneﬁt for those who are aged 65 or over when they claim.
Future changes:
The government is consulting on two changes to DLA:
A proposal to prevent the payment of the mobility component to people in residential care, in much the same way as for hospital patients (see Chapter 27), may be introduced during 2011/12, but, at the time of writing, no details were known.
Wider changes to DLA, replacing it with a ‘personal independence payment’ will not be implemented this year.
See CPAG’s online services and Welfare Rights Bulletin for updates.
(CPAG Guide 2011/12 Ch 7 Intro)

Parameter.name: use_carer_blind_system
Parameter.Description: Introduce 'Carer-Blind' needs assesment. This was analysed as an option in the Wanless Social Care review of 2006. The basic idea is that the assessment of needs (i.e. assignment to UAP levels) would not take account of whether informal care was available to the person being assessed (i.e. the UAP assessment would be based on ADLs, health and age – essentially the explanatory variables from our care needs regression – only, with no correction for the presence of informal carers from inside or outside the household.) This should (I guess) be pretty easy to implement by just having an option to adjust the option that lowers the UAP level for people who are receiving informal care.

Parameter.name: carer_blind_degree
Parameter.Description:
Number between 0 (no blindness) and 1 (full blindness). I suggest that the default option in the model is that the UAP assessment takes full account of the presence of informal carers and that the care needs of people with informal carers are reduced to ‘low/none’. However we may also want an option to reduce the care needs of people with informal carers by some degree, but not fully downgrading them to ‘low/none’. For example there could be an option to downgrade people one category (e.g. from ‘critical’ to ‘substantial’, from ‘substantial’ to ‘moderate’ etc.) So there could be intermediate options between ‘fully carer blind’ and ‘taking full account of informal carers’ (the default).
(0 = current; 0.5 = down 2 levels 0.5-0.99 down 1; 1.0 no change in levels)
